title: Wally McArthur (rugby league)
text:
Wally McArthur (1 December 1933 – 28 August 2015) was an <a href="Australian%20Aborigines">Aboriginal</a> Australian <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer and <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> athlete. In 2008, the centenary of <a href="rugby%20league%20in%20Australia">rugby league in Australia</a>, he was named in the <a href="Aboriginal%20Australian%20rugby%20league%20team">Aboriginal Australian rugby league team</a> of the Century.
McArthur was born in 1933 in <a href="Borroloola%2C%20Northern%20Territory">Borroloola</a> in the <a href="Northern%20Territory">Northern Territory</a>, before he moved down to <a href="Adelaide">Adelaide</a>, <a href="South%20Australia">South Australia</a>, in the early 1950s, where he lived at <a href="St%20Francis%20House">St Francis House</a> boys boarding home and became a noted <a href="Sprint%20%28running%29">short-distance runner</a>.
McArthur was also interested in playing <a href="Australian%20Rules%20Football">Australian Rules Football</a>, but was denied this because of a "<a href="Racism%20in%20Australia">colour bar</a>". Rugby historian Sean Fagan and Australian journalist <a href="John%20Pilger">John Pilger</a> have claimed that McArthur was not selected for the Australian track team at the <a href="1952%20Summer%20Olympics">1952 Summer Olympics</a> because of <a href="racial%20discrimination">racial discrimination</a>, but this has been disputed.
McArthur played in the <a href="South%20Australian%20Rugby%20League">South Australian Rugby League</a> and <a href="Western%20Australia%20Rugby%20League">Western Australia Rugby League</a> before moving to <a href="England">England</a> to play a total of 165 games with <a href="Rochdale%20Hornets">Rochdale Hornets</a>, <a href="Blackpool%20Borough">Blackpool Borough</a>, <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford</a> and <a href="Workington%20Town">Workington Town</a>.
